comment: This game was a 9 for me. But the alternative gameplay does not make sense. So weird, please remove the alternative rules
racist

A fun two-round auction. I like the 2nd half a little bit more (like a more gamey Hol's der Geier), but the 1st half is enjoyable too. Despite that the number progression in the 1st half is weirdly scripted, and I kinda hate this about Stefan Dorra's auction games. But it's super quick and leads to the fun 2nd half, I shouldn't complain.

Finding it a bit weird that everyone compares EVERY auction game to this one.

Now I'm just wondering why don't I just play Hol's der Geier instead and.... hrmm. Good question. Just like in Biblios, why play a crappy setup round with different rules just to get to the fun part? When other games jump ahead immediately?? To be fair, For Sale is still so much better than Biblios, but now this sticks out and makes me question this bizarre design decision. And why Eurofans love this concept in particular. I guess they prefer that players start the bids with different options (no wonder asymmetry and variable setup would become huge), and its a flaw if everyone has the same cards. Even though that’s where the groupthink is waiting (auctions! dynamics!), but they can’t identify that. But if you start with different hands from a randomized deck, like in a card game, then that’s UNFAIR and flawed. Gotta draft your opening hand, even though that doubles the game length.

What bothers me is how the bidding isn't interesting enough, usually half the player pass to get a card for free, the standard euro arc of not fighting to get a consolation prize. I guess the main problem is the strict money supply, so players don't have nearly enough money in the 1st half to bother competing for bids.

Anyway, it’s okay. I just resent this for what it’s done in the long run.

Packs a reasonable amount of clever bluffing and mind games into a radically short time. A palate cleanser, for sure, but a fairly good one at that, and something not so devoid of tactical agency as to be otherwise a random number generator. Randomness plays a part, sure, but not as large as one might initially guess; there are much larger benefits to be gained by correctly reading your opponents and knowing exactly how aggressive or risky they either will or won't be.

Auction game where you bid on properties then leverage or mortgage those properties to bid on stocks/victory points. Solidly fun with five players or larger groups. Press-your-luck kind of dynamics so you can crush one game and then lose hard the next game. Easy to teach, 10 minutes to play so nice warm-up or amuse bouche.
It's genious how much game you get out of a small stack of cards. Low rating due to it being so simple, and barely any people I've played it with want to play again because of it.

A game of two phases. Phase 1: bidding on cards of indeterminable value (which is guessing). Phase 2: blind simultaneous bidding (which is guessing). A "winner" is then announced, and everyone shrugs because it didn't feel like there was much agency involved.

What a masterwork. Easy to teach, easy to learn, and easy to play. Pretty much perfect for filler. Enough interesting decisions that strategic players will enjoy it, but enough variability that it goes down easy with players who are looking for something light. High player count that doesn't drag with six. I'll gladly play this anytime folks are looking for a filler.

A leader in its genre. Smart, quick auction game that gets right to the good stuff. Can't ask for a better filler or night starter.

For Sale is easily one of my top-tier filler games. It packs a ton into a short runtime, essentially offering two mini-games in one: a fast-paced property auction followed by a clever blind bidding phase. It plays lightning quick but still manages to present some genuinely tough decisions along the way.

What makes it shine is how accessible it is. It is very intuitive, easy to teach in just a few minutes, and the gameplay always clicks with both casual and experienced players. The shift in auction styles between phases keeps things fresh, and the artwork on the properties adds just the right touch of charm to bring the whole experience together.

It’s one of those games that somehow feels satisfying every single time. No small feat for something that plays in about 20 minutes.

A very light, tight and elegant game that never fails to instantly captivate any non-gamer after the first round.

Property Flipping-Themed, 2-Part Auction Game. (Classic Auction For House Cards, Then Blind Auction For Money Cards).
3-6 Players. (Best with 5 Players).

Always a good time, on more than one occasion has someone at the table ordered it after one or two plays. I compare it directly to High Society, and while I think HS is the stronger design, For Sale creates a more fun atmosphere.

This one literally never fails to impress. Everyone I've ever shown this to loves it and immediately wants to play again. Not much brain power required, but there is enough player interaction in the auction to generate some fun tension throughout both phases if you're paying attention while also being breezy enough to simply pass the time in a fun way if you're not.
Great filler with some tricky nuances for driving up bids and losing bids well.

Dans For Sale, les joueurs vont acheter des maisons aux enchères, puis proposer leurs biens aux acquéreurs. L’agent immobilier le plus riche à la fin de la partie sera sacré meilleur chasseur d’appart!

For Sale est un jeu sympathique qui plaira assurément aux joueurs de Poker. Si vous aimez bluffer, l’immobilier et l’émission Storage Wars, vous aimerez ce jeu. Iello nous livre ici un bon opus dans sa gamme Mini.

A perfect design: simple, anyone can play, short

8.0 - Half a dozen plays on BGA - Such a clever little filler. Definitely there's a lot of double guessing, and I do think there's probably a lot of luck, but it at feels like you have control (similar to 6Nimt!). The bidding system where you get back half your coins unless you win is brilliant. Evaluating what to bid in either phase A or B based on the current selection is a very difficult decision. Very eager to see how it goes over in person with my group!

8.0 - 2 live plays with 5 and 2 more with 4 - Went over really well in both groups. The decisions are so good in such a quick package! Both phases have great moments with a different feel. I like that the first phase is more calculating and the second for of a donkey space. I suspect this'll be my go to filler!

9.0 - 13 plays - This is the perfect filler. The decisions are so agonizing.
Wow, the epitome of less is more.
